Dialogue: Yeah, Silly, I meant after.

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: Cool! Let's get a group together.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Yeah, definitely! Or just the two of us. Scott looks around, then lowers his voice.

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: Oh. Um, listen, I'm really flattered. You're one of the nicest people I've met here. But... I'm actually seeing someone.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Oh?

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: Yeah, we've been keeping it quiet.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Because she's ugly?

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: No. She's beautiful. She's great. She really cares about the kids. It's just... when you're dating a co-worker...

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: Anyways, thanks again for asking me out. I'm honored. And I'll take a raincheck on that group date. See ya! Scott crosses through the cafeteria. Lynn returns with a four cartons of milk.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Here you go. I got you one of each.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Hi, my name's Elizabeth Halsey. Soooooo... Any questions? Sasha's Mother eagerly raises her hand. Elizabeth points to her.

Speaker: sasha's mother
Dialogue: Hi, I'm Sasha's mother. We waved to each other at the carwash. I'm a little concerned with the importance you're placing on movies. What about the state test? Elizabeth points to her sign on the wall -- "Don't Question My Authority."

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: That's exactly what I say to my students. Listen, I'm a good teacher. And the school hired me because I'm good at what I do.  And the reason your son loves my class is because I inspire him. Movies are one tool that I use. I also use other multimedia techniques, which I'm not going to get into right now. Look, I could take you day by day through my entire syllabus, but that's not how I do things. I'm not one of these stuffy teachers who's totally by the book. I talk to the kids like they're little adults. It's about mutual respect. So that's my spiel, as the Jews say.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Chris... Great kid -- and precocious. You must be so proud.

Speaker: chris' dad
Dialogue: Oh, what a relief. I just wish his grades would reflect it.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: If I know Chris, he'll get there.

Speaker: chris' dad
Dialogue: Listen, I know you have a full plate, but if you could keep an eye on Chris, my wife and I would really appreciate it. Chris' dad shakes her hand. Elizabeth opens her hand, sees a tightly folded HUNDRED DOLLAR bill. She looks back up at Chris' dad.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: You're Chase's parents? Great kid -- and precocious. You must be so proud. The parents beam.

Speaker: chase's mom
Dialogue: You think we should hire a tutor?  I told you.

Speaker: chase's mom
Dialogue: Oh, to be a teacher.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: It's just so hard, on my salary, having to pay for my supplies, my fiance cheated on me with his twin sister... and, unlike a lot of these other teachers, all I truly care about is helping your child learn. And as their personal tutor, I guarantee a full grade higher -- or your money back. Chase's mom takes out her check book.

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: Excuse me, Ms. Halsey. I just wanted to introduce myself. I'm Melody. Garrett's mom.

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: Oh, you're referring to his poetry. Thank you.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: You must be so proud.

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: I am. So so so so so proud. So proud.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: A kid like that, if I could just give some more one on one time, he would just blossom.

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: I'm so happy to hear you say that. would really benefit from that.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Unfortunately, in a class of twenty- five...

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: Ugh. Class sizes are ridiculous.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: And with the amount they pay teachers...

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: Thank god you love what you do.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I guess what I'm getting at is, maybe you could help out by giving me a little -- you know -- somethin somethin. Elizabeth offers her hand, palm up. Melody stares back at her blankly.

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: You know what I'm going to do for you? Melody opens her pocketbook. Elizabeth smiles.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: So long, Crazy. As Elizabeth pulls out the CASH she just made, we hear the opening beats of COOLIO'S "GANGSTER'S PARADISE."

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Enough with the commotion! The hallway goes silent. She comes back in and UNPAUSES the movie. The SONG comes back on.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: What do you want? Sasha motions for her to roll down the window. Elizabeth doesn't.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Is that marijuana?

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: It is. But it's medicinal. Doctor gave it to me. Not that it's any of your business.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Oh, okay. Feel better.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Are those oatmeal raisin?

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Sugar. Elizabeth considers, then manually rolls down the window a crack. She grabs the container and quickly closes her window. Elizabeth starts eating a cookie.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: You have anything to drink? Sasha shakes her head.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: I don't want to run for congress. I want to be president.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: See? That's what I'm talking about. Keep saying stuff like that, you're gonna get punched. You really want to be President or is that what your parents tell to be? Sasha shrugs.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: If I think about it, will I get extra credit?

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Hopeless. Watch your feet.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Seriously?

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Seriously? She sees a HOMELESS GUY leaning against the storefront.

Speaker: homeless guy
Dialogue: It's Christmas.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Seriously? Elizabeth looks around. The streets are empty. Not a person in sight.

Speaker: homeless guy
Dialogue: Merry Christmas!

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Whatever.  Hey, you got a lighter?

Speaker: homeless guy
Dialogue: I don't smoke. It's bad for you. Elizabeth walks back to her car, empty-handed. A MINI- VAN passes. Stops. Reverses.. The window rolls down. It's Garrett and his Mom.

Speaker: garrett
Dialogue: Ms. Halsey! Hey, it's me, Garrett!

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: Merry Christmas, Ms. Halsey!

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: Having a nice Christmas?

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: What are you doing the rest of the day? Going to see your family?

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: Ms. Halsey.  Elizabeth. Would you like to have Christmas with us?

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: This is a real treat for Garrett. He doesn't have a lot of friends come by the house.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I find that hard to believe.

Speaker: garrett
Dialogue: I thought we could play board games!

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Yeah, I love helping bums.

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: Oh, but you have to wait for dessert. We have a real treat.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: If it's cheesecake, I'll stay.

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: It's even better than cheesecake!

Speaker: garrett
Dialogue: Oh god, no one wants to hear it. Oh god, I'm so embarrassed!

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: Don't be shy, Marbles. Garrett runs out of the room.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: If you're not really serving dessert, I'm gonna have to get going.

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: One poem? If you like it, maybe you can read it to your homeless friends.

Speaker: garrett
Dialogue: This is called "The Chase," by Garrett Tiara.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: She sits back down.

Speaker: garrett
Dialogue: We'll dance our dance / We'll revel in romance perchance / One glance / One dance / Because together we can achieve...  Ba-lance... Thank you. He closes his journal. Everyone applauds. Melody looks to Elizabeth for a reaction.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Junior likes to rhyme.

Speaker: melody
Dialogue: Patty, Nancy, why don't you give me a hand with dessert -- give them a chance to talk about the poem. The women exit, leaving Garrett and Elizabeth.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: So your poem's about that girl?

Speaker: garrett
Dialogue: Chase, yeah. You got the subtext.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Can I give you some advice?

Speaker: garrett
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Number one, stop writing poetry. Two: stop reading it. And three: don't set your sights so high. I mean, she's really hot. If I were you, I'd try for that chubby girl that sits up front -- the one with the teeth? Elizabeth puts her hands to show teeth going off in different directions.

Speaker: garrett
Dialogue: But I like Chase.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Not gonna happen. Look, I was that hot girl. Hotter, even. And I never would have gone out with a kid like you. And I'm not saying that to be mean. I'm saying it to be helpful.

Speaker: garrett
Dialogue: What do you know? You don't-even know our names.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I'll tell you what I know: a kid who wears the same "Gymnastics" sweatshirt three days a week isn't getting laid

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Well, there's a reason he didn't pack it.

Speaker: garrett
Dialogue: Fuck you. Elizabeth pats Garrett on the shoulder.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Good luck being a loser. Thank your mom for dinner. Elizabeth heads for the door.

Speaker: garrett
Dialogue: Happy New Year. Are you spending that alone, too, or do you want my mom to invite you over? She gives him the finger over her shoulder and leaves.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Shut up.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Hey, welcome back.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: What is that, vomit? Lynn grabs some towels and blots at the stain..

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Yeah, and a little blood. The kids had too much sugar.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Ugh. No. Elizabeth heads out. Lynn, still blotting, follows her.

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: Hey, guys. Are you coming to 'In Cahoots' tonight? My band's doing a few songs. Could be fun.

Dialogue: Um, yes! That sounds like a party.  Lynn, do you want to come?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Yes.

Dialogue: We'll all grab a drink!

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Great. I need to get drunk. I mean, not drunk drunk. But a strong buzz. Still be able to drive home.

Dialogue: Now we're cooking with grease!

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: Rockabye, rockabye...

Dialogue: Bye, bye... Bye, bye...

Dialogue: Elizabeth and Lynn at the bar.

Dialogue: Aren't they terrific? Elizabeth eye-fucks Scott. She catches his eye and he quickly smiles before nervously turning his attention to Amy. Elizabeth watches Amy dance in SLO M0, her BREASTS bouncing up and down.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: They're perfect.

Dialogue: You should hear some of their originals. She turns to the bartender.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Two more.  You want anything?

Dialogue: No thanks... You know, I was thinking that if you still need that money, you should.try and go for the bonus. Can't hurt.

Dialogue: What bonus?

Speaker: lynn

Dialogue: How much?

Dialogue: Cold.

Dialogue: What do you think's going on? Spencer shrugs.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Come on, come on. We have a lot to cover so sit down. The class, still confused, quickly take their seats.

Dialogue: Because she's a cry baby. The kids chuckle. Chase looks back at Garrett.

Dialogue: You never assigned it to us.

Dialogue: Well, now I am. And we're having a quiz tomorrow. Panic.

Dialogue: Hey! Zip your shit! We've fallen behind, and honestly, your practice tests scores sucked balls -- which was embarrassing to me both on a personal level and as an educator.

Dialogue: Did you get my Cool Ranch? He tosses her a bag of chips.

Dialogue: Okay, now, what is the significance of the Mockingbird in the novel? What was Harper Lee trying to tell us? No one raises their hand.

Dialogue: Use examples from the book.

Dialogue: It doesn't matter what race the defendant is. You've just gotta look at the facts-. Elizabeth nods in agreement. The bell RINGS.

Dialogue: Good work today. And don't forget to leave your closing statements on my desk.

Dialogue: So, you know how I hate to gossip, but I heard that one of the custodians walked in on Omar -- you know, that Arabic boy -- giving...

Dialogue: Hey, Ms. Halsey.

Dialogue: I don't know. I told you about the car wash money.

Dialogue: Whoa. Drug dogs. Cool.

Dialogue: Sit down. Elizabeth races to the window.

Dialogue: The Police officers and the dogs enter the classroom next to hers. Elizabeth glances back at her pocketbook.

Dialogue: Elizabeth, sorry to bother you. This will only take a second. Elizabeth,. still choking, digs into her purse. She grabs her cough syrup and takes a huge swig. Elizabeth wipes her mouth, breathes normally.

Dialogue: Sorry. I had something caught in my throat. The German Shepherd continues barking.

Dialogue: Ahhh!!! The'Police Officer starts rummaging through Garrett's bag and pulls out an opened bag of CORN CHIPS.

Dialogue: Even though that wasn't drugs, junk food is still contraband. That's detention, Buster.

Speaker: principal snur
Dialogue: Enough, Amy. I think it's time we call off this witch-hunt.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Thank you, Principal Snur. Now if you'll excuse me, my class has a state test to prepare for. Principal Snur, Amy and the Police Officer exit. Elizabeth slumps down into her chair, and all at once, the combination of WEED and COUGH SYRUP HITS HER.

Speaker: chase
Dialogue: Are you okay, Ms. Halsey? Elizabeth takes a long beat before answering.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Class dismissed.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: But the bell didn't ring.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Get out of my face.  And leave the corn chips. The class uncertainly gathers their things and heads out. From outside Elizabeth's window, we SEE the SCHOOL BUSSES idling curbside. Elizabeth stares at the papers she still needs to grade. The papers stare back at her.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Balls! She knocks the stack of ungraded papers to the ground. After a beat, she collects herself, goes to pick the, papers off the floor. As she starts tossing them into the trash, something catches her eye: a PRACTICE TEST MANUAL. And in the corner, an address:

Speaker: frat guy
Dialogue: Hi there.

Dialogue: Is Tucker here?

Dialogue: Do you ever talk to my brother?

Dialogue: No. He dumped me, remember?

Speaker: tucker
Dialogue: You and my brother always had the histrionics.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Like I told "Frat Guy #1," I'm not interested.

Speaker: tucker
Dialogue: Then what's up?

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I need some date rape drugs.

Speaker: tucker
Dialogue: Two things. Number one: who do you think I am? Yeah, I like to party and yeah, I'm in an awesome frat, but that really hurts. And two: they're not "date rape" drugs. It's called GHB -- and it's for weightlifting. It helps build mass, okay? Why do you even want it?

Speaker: tucker
Dialogue: That's all you needed to say. No need to get all histrionic on me. Tucker walks over to a chest, opens it, and takes out a small lockbox. He unlocks it and takes out a small bottle containing a clear liquid.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Get your hand off my ass.

Speaker: tucker
Dialogue: Sorry, didn't even know I put it down there. Good luck with your lifting.

Dialogue: Marjorie? "Marjorie" turns and we SEE that it's actually ELIZABETH, wearing the "Little Orphan Annie" wig. She's sipping a cocktail.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: You must be Carl. His face lights up, excited to be in the company of such an attractive woman. Elizabeth stands and extends her hand. Carl notices Elizabeth's very short skirt.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Great drive. I love downstate Illinois.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: First time to Peoria?

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Hmm mmm.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: A lot of people don't know this, but it's the largest city on the Illinois River.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Wow. I did not know that.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Yup yup. And it was actually founded before Chicago.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Hello, Jeopardy! Have you ever auditioned?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: No. I should, I should. Definitely thought about it.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Listen, I'd love to sit here and chat with you all night.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Yeah...

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: But I'm sure you're a very busy man, so I'll get right down to it.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: You can't use my name, okay?

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: No problem.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Like I told you on the phone, every couple of years, we get calls from all over the state with these cockamamie charges. You should hear what they call me. And I'm not a racist. I voted for Obama.  That, you can quote me on.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Oh, right. Elizabeth takes out a notebook and pen and starts jotting down notes.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Look, Marjorie, I know my tests aren't perfect. But what's the alternative? I'm all for free thinking and creativity, but how do you formulate an education budget without hard numbers from one of my tests?

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: You don't need to convince me. But you know what would help, Carl? For me to see one of this year's tests.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: No problem at all. Elizabeth lights up.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: I'd really love to see it sooner. I'm on a bit of a deadline.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: I wish I could, but unfortunately, you need one of these bad boys. Carl holds up a lanyard with a STATE ID CARD and some keys attached.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Ooh, you look like you're CIA. Listen, I totally get it. Enough business for one night.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: My poison is the white devil. Wine. White wine.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Fantastic.  One white wine, one tequila sunrise, and two shots of tequila.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: You know, Marjorie, this is the best night I've had in a longtime.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Well, that makes two of us. Elizabeth gives Carl "fuck me" eyes. He nervously sips his drink.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Everything.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: You know what turns me on, Carl? He giggles nervously.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Even better.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: So this is the desk.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Do you have anything to drink? Carl goes to a mini-fridge and pulls out an already opened bottle of white wine.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Um... I could put on some internet radio. Carl goes to fiddle with his computer. Elizabeth quickly reaches into her purse and pulls out the bottle of GHB. She pours a little into Carl's wine. And then a little bit more. As he turns around, she hands him the glass.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: A toast. To new friends.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: To new lovers. CLINK. Carl downs his glass.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Whatever, man. I'm gonna hit the lady's room.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: K, first door on your right. Don't be long. Carl starts carefully clearing everything off of his desk.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Easy, Cowboy. Carl stumbles towards her. Elizabeth deftly moves around the desk and exits into the bullpen.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Marblorie!

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Carl, I'm gonna need you to pass the fuck out. Carl smiles as he feebly chases after her. He. stops at the photocopier, steadies himself momentarily and then passes out, STILL STANDING. Elizabeth grabs the lanyard from Carl's neck and heads back into his office. She goes over to the filing cabinets, unlocks it with one of the keys, and starts rifling. She pulls out a folder.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Okay, go. The students open their test books and start. Twenty- five pencils hit paper in unison.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Okay, pencils down. A couple of groans. A couple of frantic moves to fill in more scantron bubbles.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: If anyone has any information regarding the whereabouts of the missing "Annie" wig, please let me know ASAP. Because if that wig isn't found, you can bet your bottom dollar the "sun will not come out tomorrow." Back to you, Wally. Amy sits. Principal Snur addresses the teachers.

Speaker: principal snur
Dialogue: Thanks, Amy. Um, okay, I'm sure everyone wants to go home, so I'll be quick.

Speaker: principal snur
Dialogue: So I have here the results of the state exam -- and I'm happy to announce that John Adams Middle School had the fifth highest scores in the state. The Teachers applaud.

Dialogue: Oh boy, third year in a row. This is starting to get embarrassing.

Speaker: principal snur
Dialogue: Elizabeth Halsey! Elizabeth leans over to Amy, who's sitting beside her.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: This is unexpected. All of the color drains from Amy's face as Elizabeth stands and waves at the crowd.

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: Hey, if it isn't Professor Smartypants. Scott playfully punches her shoulder. Elizabeth playfully punches him back.

Speaker: elizabeth
Dialogue: Something big. Maybe two big things. Amy walks up and gives Elizabeth a big, fake hug.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Hey! Ism so proud of you. If someone told me at the beginning of the year that you -- you! -- would get the bonus, I would've said to whomever it was, 'you must be joshing me.' And now, here we are. Here we are.

Speaker: scott
Dialogue: We should go out and celebrate.  Your treat?

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: What a good, fun idea. Unfortunately, Scott and I have to go over the itinerary for the D.C. trip. We're the chaperones. We're going together.  We're dating, so it'll also be romantic. You're not dating anyone now, right?

Dialogue: I've got my eye on someone, but he's dating a major cunt.  Pardon my French.

Dialogue: No, she sounds terrible.

Dialogue: She is.

Dialogue: Rain check on those drinks.

Dialogue: And this is endorsed. And the rest you can put on these. Elizabeth slides four credit cards across the desk. The MIDDLE-AGED DOCTOR from earlier walks by.

Dialogue: Today. Tomorrow. As soon as possible. Danni checks her calendar.

Dialogue: Book it. Danni slides Elizabeth a packet of literature.

Dialogue: We have a 48 hour cancellation policy. Anything after that, you'll be charged 50% the cost of the surgery -- unless there are extenuating circumstances.

Dialogue: All set?

Dialogue: I think we're good.

Dialogue: Is Amy going to be okay?

Dialogue: She'll be fine. But to be honest, I think she was scaring some of the kids.

Dialogue: I bet, I bet. Well, let her know she's in my thoughts.

Dialogue: Amy watching from outside her car. One side of her face is completely blistered, scaly and red from the POISON IVY. The kids have every reason to be scared by her. She gets into her car and slams the door.

Dialogue: Fudge! Fudge! Fudge! Fuuuuuck--dge!

Dialogue: I think I hear it again!

Dialogue: Mr. Delacourte, do you think we could go to the poetry museum?

Dialogue: Oh, um, I don't know, Champ, um -- Scott looks to Elizabeth, like "please help."

Dialogue: Just go sit down, sweetie. Garrett gives her an annoyed look and then heads back to his seat. Scott smiles at Elizabeth.
